commits.commitMessage:
Add Data Mode Support to External UART port

Expose few functions of externalUART to data mode PA to access the
it, and update the callback function to driver for reuse in data
mode.

Resolves: LE-16302 LE-16303 LE-16304 LE-16305
Change-Id: I878d5dbffc9c6e35caf66d8fea938d2b08e31abe
commits.subject: Add Data Mode Support to External UART port

comments.message: I think we should use externalSerial_GetSerialHandle() instead of directly referencing the device.

commits.commitMessage:
Compress all rw memory to GPM

Only GPM memory is retained on entry to standby mode.  Since we
use more memory than can be fit into GPM, add logic to compress all
used memory into GPM.

Resolves: LE-15901
Change-Id: If0a64f019aafd551ebe04b2b275a92e5049c0efd
commits.subject: Compress all rw memory to GPM

commits.commitMessage:
Create power management API for MCU

Create a power management API for the MCU which will support preparing
a system for hibernation, and restoring the system to normal running
state once hibernation is complete.  The logic of entering hibernation
itself is provided in part by SSI, and the remaining integration code
will be located in the idle task.

Also supports some debug functions for use in the memRetenDbg command.

Resolves: LE-15900
Change-Id: I56ed1f366d94c76d903acef13c7ee3853b919f61
commits.subject: Create power management API for MCU

commits.commitMessage:
Dump registers r4 to r11 in the exception handler.

Registers r4 to r11 are caller-preserved registers, so are not
pushed to the stack as part of the exception handling process, and
can be dumped directly.  Add code to the exception handling stub
to dump these to the stack on entry, and pass a pointer to this
memory region to the C dumper function so it can output them to
the console.

Resolves: LE-16060
Change-Id: I852e65d887cce713a8cd7d4e753e4d8759b5d670
commits.subject: Dump registers r4 to r11 in the exception handler.

commits.commitMessage:
Add Static Command Registry and External UART

[LE-15443] - Implements the Static Command Registry in the AT Proxy.
It provides the following features,

1) Implements AT Proxy Legato API functions to support,
    adding AT command handler callback functions,
    removing AT command handler callback functions,
    sending Intermediate, Final, Error, and Unsolicited Responses,

2) Statically-defined table to hold registered command handler
callback functions for each "local" AT Command.

3) An Internal look-up function to retrieve the AT command handler
callback functions for a specified AT command.

[LE-15444] - Implements connection to external UART (stdout/console) for
sending and receiving AT content from the AT Proxy.

[LE-15445] - Implement the AT Proxy to provide Local Command Handling
behaviour, including:

1) Parse the STDOUT/console input to identify incoming AT commands,
2) Create and manage the AT Command session for the tracking AT
command being processed,
3) Retrieve (look-up) the command handler callback function from the
Static Command Registry associated with the AT command,
4) Trigger the IPC Command Handler callback function associated with
the AT command to notify local Back-end (ORP) that an AT command has arrived.
5) Write all Final, Intermediate, Error, and Unsolicited Response strings
to the STDOUT/console port.

Resolves: LE-15443 LE-15444 LE-15445
Change-Id: I20549db371be6c655bb7d44ca3d69ae9a8de26a4
commits.subject: Add Static Command Registry and External UART

comments.message:
doesn't need to be global,
can be defined within ExternalSerialPortOpen
This has already been addressed in a later patch.

Do we wanna have a better name for this file?
something that clearly attaches it to UARTF0?

you can make ACTIVE_UARTF0 a member of externalSerial_t and set it here.
I've changed the externalSerial_t structure to have a member called instance, which is set to ACTIVE_UARTF0, so that this is explicitly declared and more obvious.

what is this value?
shouldn't it block forever if it's defined a blocking?

does this need to be here?
I think it's only needed within the externalSerial.c file.
This doesn't need to be a global, it can just be local to ExternalSerialPortOpen().
This should not be an array.  There is only a single device.
This should just be one static instance, I think.
Is there a reason this is exactly == 1 and not >= 1?

The idea behind this is that we only want to signal the FD device when the first byte (character) arrives.   No need to signal again on subsequent bytes, because the client is expected to read until the buffer is empty.   This is similar to how it has been done for the internalSerial case.
But if we arrive here and two bytes are already queued, nothing will happen, which seems undesirable.  Is externalSerialPortCallback() guaranteed to be called once for each individual byte?

Even in the case you describe, this code would have signalled the FD on the arrival of the first byte.  The fact that there are now two bytes waiting is only because the POLLIN hasn't been serviced yet, and more bytes have been queued.   However, once the asynchronous callback function is triggered, it will read all bytes that are waiting in the queue (i.e. two bytes).  The next subsequent byte to arrive will once again signal the FD device because the queue is now empty, and things will repeat again.  

The goal of doing it this way is to reduce the number of FD signals that are generated.   As previously mentioned, this is already being used in the internalSerial device.
No loop needed, just create the single instance.
Comment is still incorrect (referencing EMUX properties).
I am not sure, so do we only check POLLIN here?

This function is used to generate POLLIN events on a specified file descriptor (FD), as part of the FD Monitor service.   Once it has been signalled, the atProxyCmdHandler_AsyncRecvHandler() receive handler will be triggered to act on it.

commits.commitMessage:
Add NULL check in le_interrupt_AddNotifier()

If the interrupt notifier pool is empty, le_interruptAddNotifier()
will receive a NULL pointer from le_mem_TryAlloc() and dereference
that NULL pointer.

Resolves: LE-15507
Change-Id: Id8737b30205cd49c710d09c77a7dc1c71323cf5f
commits.subject: Add NULL check in le_interrupt_AddNotifier()

comments.message:
good patch,
one thing, do you wanna print a warning here if notifier was null?

I thought about it, but there is a NULL return in that case, and it's possible that the caller may find a way to handle it gracefully (otherwise we might as well have just done an LE_ASSERT in here).  I don't want to clutter the logs with warnings during normal operation.  In my use case (in SensorHub), we just LE_ASSERT() that the reference returned is not NULL, so we'd get a log message for that anyway.

commits.commitMessage:
Fix queued functions starve timers

Previously on Altair MCU, if a queued function re-queues itself
using le_event_QueueFunction(), then timers are starved. This is
because the framework adaptor's fa_event_WaitForEvent() quits the
loop before checking timer events. In a situation that there is
always a pending event such as a self-queuing function, the timer
will be starved. So, this patch queues the timer handler to the
event queue if timer expires, and moves the code of checking
pending events after checking timer.

Resolves: LE-15046
Change-Id: I411f79226d58a33b48add59e0f5d01002c5c2829
commits.subject: Fix queued functions starve timers

comments.message: Note that this will have the side effect of making timer expiries jump to the front of the event queue. The result could be that a time-out may be reported for an event that actually occurred before the time-out deadline. To prevent this, the timer expiry event needs to be queued to the event queue.
Hi Jen, I have made a change to queue the timer handler to the event queue.

I don't think stopping the physical timer is necessary. The timer subsystem takes care of all that inside timer_Handler(), which will run before returning back to the event loop and waiting for events again.  Besides, the "physical timer" is not really a physical timer.  It's just a "next timeout" field in the per-thread record. So, we just need to make sure that gets updated before fa_event_WaitForEvent() gets called again, and timer_Handler() will do that.

(Sorry, I should have noticed that before.)

Hi Jen, I tried commenting out fa_timer_StopTimer(timerRecPtr); which causes an ASSERT when the timer gets the number of Trail:
Jan  1 00:02:37 :  INFO | framework T=testTimerCmd | testTimer.c 10 | In timer handler---------------------------------, i=999
Jan  1 00:02:37 :  INFO | framework T=testTimerCmd | testTimer.c 18 | In DeferredFunc, j=10788
Jan  1 00:02:37 : *EMR* | framework T=testTimerCmd | timer.c 458 | Assert Failed: 'NULL != firstTimerPtr'
Aborted!
Backtrace:
    00: 18A038CC
    01: 18A0AC6E
    02: 18A10838
    03: 18A06D1A
    04: 18A06DC6
    05: 18A10956
    06: 18A0789A
    07: 189D300E
    08: 18A0E866
    09: 18A23C48
    10: 18A1C5F0

After looking at the code some more, I see that there is a bug in timer_Handler() that has been addressed by calling fa_timer_StopTimer() in the event loop FA code. This timer code could use some refactoring for maintainability. But, that's a topic for another ticket. So, for now, I can live with calling fa_timer_StopTimer() here.

I think the comment "and stop the timer to avoid re-firing the same timer" is not totally accurate, though.  It should probably be changed to something like "and stop the physical timer to prevent triggering a bug in timer_Handler()", or maybe, "and stop the physical timer (will be restarted by the timer subsystem, as needed)."
Thanks Jen for discussion this on slack, I have made this change in patchset 4.
Should we check if the timer record pointer is valid (not NULL) before accessing it?
Right, we'd better do a NULL check here.
This will never return NULL.  A check for NULL would be a waste of CPU cycles (= battery life).
Hi Jen, the concern I have here is that one of the "pending" Legato events that get processed before this could free the timer behind our back, and result in a crash.

Yeah, I like that thinking, but this is not getting a pointer to a timer. It's getting a pointer to the "timer record" in the thread-local data structure. This is the timer subsystem's per-thread data structure, which contains the active timer list, etc.
Could pass this as param1Ptr to save having to call thread_GetTimerRecPtr().

commits.commitMessage:
Run CLI commands within Legato event loop thread

Create a process and start a thread for each CLI command instead of calling
its COMPONENT_INIT directly in context of serial console task.

Resolves: LE-14649
Change-Id: I816b3bb9c01ca4f6b3f38b2e5d9573048dc3e6de
commits.subject: Run CLI commands within Legato event loop thread

comments.message: Please don't change this.  It is known to work on the MCU.
On the MCU we are using Newlib, so you could also use strlcpy(), but if not then I think changing to snprintf() is reasonable.

commits.commitMessage:
Fix crash if function queued in not started thread

If a function is queued in the eventloop of a thread that is not ran
yet, its task does not need to be notified. The event will be picked up once
the evenloop starts for the first time.

Resolves: LE-15159
Change-Id: I94e92054d0bbd38caf22ab9a3523504233634c3c
commits.subject: Fix crash if function queued in not started thread

Ok for moving this into a hl78-mcu specific framework adaptor for Legato.

commits.commitMessage:
Add Interrupt Notifiers

Interrupt Notifiers are used on RTOS to allow an interrupt
service routine to wake up a task running the Legato event
loop and call a registered handler callback.

Resolves: LE-14923
Change-Id: Id27d38d1edb324d094b386e03290022c96fb7d2a
commits.subject: Add Interrupt Notifiers

comments.message: Minor thing, but the fa_ prefix is typically used for the internal API between the common parts of liblegato and the framework adaptor.  I would recommend just dropping the fa_ part in this context.
See my note in the other patch about stdatomic.h.  I'm okay with it in this code as long as the platform/toolchain combination supports it.

Does this comment still make sense?  My interpretation is that it's referring to the fact that it would break before doing the xTaskNotifyWait that is now above this statement.  What was the reason for moving this block lower in the function?

It still breaks before checking for expired timers and handling them, so the comment isn't totally wrong.  Regardless, this is just a temporary hack that will have to be replaced when https://issues.sierrawireless.com/browse/LE-15046 is fixed.
This is an odd include guard given the name of this file.  Was this accidental?

Yep. Accident. When I originally started writing this thing, I was planning to build a FIFO that ISRs can push interrupt reports into, along with data associated with the event. Later, I realized I just need to wake the Legato event loop. If the ISR needs to queue data to the task too, it can use a separate FreeRTOS Queue or other data structure, and the task can pull from that Queue when it wakes up.
Acknowledged. I don't disagree with you. I just don't think it matters much either way. They are both clear, readable, and correct.

commits.commitMessage:
Liblegato improvements needed for rpcFileStream

    - Add workaround for fd monitors of stdout and POLLOUT event.
    - Add LE_FD_FIFO_GET_AVAILABLE_SPACE request to ioctl that returns
          available space in fifo
    - Handle stdout, stdin, stderr cases in le_fd_Write

Resolves: LE-14677
Change-Id: I2eaff79c119ee8292edf78494677d807f519bbf7
commits.subject: Liblegato improvements needed for rpcFileStream

comments.message:
so this number essentially reports the capacity of stdout.now if we don't consider the uart baud rate, it's hard to report a number for stdout capacity because theoretically we should be able to write to it as much as we want. but I have to report a number for file stream to support stdout on rtos hence this number.
All in all it's not a performance tuning parameter that's why left it here.

commits.commitMessage:
Activate internal UART communication between MCU and MAP on RK3.0

Changes to support Altair's EMUX library and use virtual port for
communication between MCU and MAP.
Handle single type of events in MCU event loop (for now). Other event types
are for future use.

Resolves: LE-14457
Change-Id: I579ed237720e483776530928306f7710bf79d6e4
commits.subject: Activate internal UART communication between MCU and MAP on RK3.0

comments.message: If we are not planning to add support for these cases in the next 5-6 months, then it is probably better not to have it in code.

the generally looks solid.

The thing about header is that we had to add it when we created our own mux here and it wasn't need when only one device was using internal uart.

Although it's no harm to have it.
Similar to my previous comment.   I think this name should better reflect the type of device.

I am not sure about it.
This can be viewed as binding point between app and virtual port (similar to UART mapping in manager file on MAP side).
Do you know if the rpc recovers after a while if any of these fails?

comments.message:
I know this is copied code, but please reformat it according to our coding style.

I'm not convinced that this implementation is actually good (I know it comes from Altair).  It doesn't seem to be able to trim (i.e. use a negative incr value to lower the system break), and it doesn't appear to zero the memory, which is needed if newlib was built with MORECORE_CLEARS set to 1 (the default).
Move these macro definitions outside of the function.
HEAP_SIZE isn't actually used at all here.

Add atomFile_Init in atomFile.c

atomFile_Init is added in microsupervisor since atomFile API is
supported on ThreadX now. Since ThreadX and FreeRTOS share
microsupervisor code, it is needed on HL78 to pass compiling.

commits.commitMessage:
Replace strerror() and strerror_r() with LE_ERRNO_TXT()

strerror() and strerror_r() have different behaviour and different
prototypes depending on the system.  So replace these with a new
function LE_ERRNO_TXT() which will behave like strerror() but is
thread safe.

Resolves: LE-14026
Change-Id: I09a872d03b207886f3459b10b406079dc88f8463
commits.subject: Replace strerror() and strerror_r() with LE_ERRNO_TXT()

Add stub implementation for fa_clk_SetTimezoneFile

A common API has been added to configure timezone files on RTOS
platforms. This changeset adds a stub implementation for HL78.

commits.commitMessage:
le_comm interface for MCU <-> MAP communication

Set the task handle for the event loop record in the correct context

Resolves: LE-13090
Change-Id: I2b19818819bd8bd73d561717815b21d9909f562d
commits.subject: le_comm interface for MCU <-> MAP communication

comments.message: fa_event_CreatePerThreadInfo gets called in event_CreatePerThreadInfo which itself is called in CreateThread(inside thread.c). that is before the thread being created as started. so this is the context of the parent task. so the "xTaskGetCurrentTaskHandle()" would result in the wrong task handle being stored in the recPtr of the child task. I removed it from here and did in the fa_event_ThreadInit below instead which is in the child task.
